message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the seasons and the way the Earth's axial tilt affects the amount of daylight in different regions. The end of June is the best time to have an all-day BBQ in the northern hemisphere because it is the summer solstice, which is the day with the longest period of daylight. Option (A) and (B) are incorrect because December 21st and the winter solstice have the shortest period of daylight in the year. Option (D) is also incorrect because January is still within the winter season and has shorter days compared to the end of June.

This question requires knowledge about the seasons and the position of the sun in the northern hemisphere. The best time to have an all-day BBQ in the northern hemisphere is at the end of June, around the summer solstice. This is because during this time, the sun is at its highest point in the sky and the days are the longest, providing ample daylight for a BBQ. Option (A) and (B) are incorrect because December 21st and the winter solstice mark the shortest days of the year with less daylight. Option (D) is incorrect because January is still in the winter season and does not offer the same amount of daylight as the end of June.

To answer this question, we need to understand the seasons and the position of the sun in the sky during different times of the year in the northern hemisphere. The end of June, specifically around June 21st, is the summer solstice. During this time, the northern hemisphere is tilted towards the sun, resulting in longer daylight hours and generally warmer temperatures. This makes it the ideal time for an all-day BBQ because there is more sunlight and the weather is warmer. Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because they are either in the winter months or not during the time of the year when the northern hemisphere receives the most sunlight.
